Based on your preferences, here are a few movie recommendations that you might enjoy:

- "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind" (2004): This romantic comedy follows two people who fall in love with each other, but then decide to end their relationship forever. Starring Mark Ruffalo and Jim Carrey.

- "White Chicks" (2004): This comedy horror movie follows a group of two professional white guys - Ray (Bill Murray) and Phil (Dan Aykroyd)) - who are hired by a woman named Sarah (Janeane Garofalo)) - to kidnap her sister, Susie (Milla Dvokovic)), from New York City. The two white men are initially hesitant about the kidnapping job but soon become desperate for money and quickly agree to go along with the kidnapping plan. However, things go awry when the two white guys end up getting into a fight with some unknown black dudes while they're trying to kidnap one of their own family members from New York City.

- "Ocean' s Twelve" (2004): This action comedy movie follows a group of twelve highly skilled and experienced FBI agents who are given the task of pulling off three major European heists in order to save the lives of thousands of innocent people who may be endangered by the actions of some unknown rogue European terrorist organization.

Based on your preferences, I would highly recommend watching "The Fighter." This movie stars Mark Wahlberg and Micky Ward, who are both known for their boxing skills.

The story of "The Fighter" revolves around an up-and-coming fighter named Micky Ward, who is seeking to break out of the shadow of his older brother, a former professional boxer who has struggled with addiction and mental health issues.

As Micky faces off against some of the most formidable fighters in the world, he must confront not only the physical demands of the sport, but also the emotional toll that comes with being a professional athlete.

In "The Fighter," director David O. Sillanay brings together an impressive cast of actors, including Mark Wahlberg, Micky Ward, Amy Adams, Christian Bale, Christian Bale, etc., to create a compelling and engaging movie experience.
